Architects of Existence.title: Architects of Existence
Architects of Existence.label: Carpe Sonum Records
Architects of Existence.about: Mick Chillage, the hardest working man in (ambient) show business, has joined forces with Eric “the” Taylor to make our daily lives go down just a bit sweeter. They’ve coined themselves the Architects of Existence, and, yes, it’s a weighty moniker, but listening to these four epic-lengths pieces of broadband drift you’re happy that the dynamic duo’s at least got lofty ambitions. It’s pleasing to know that between them they’ve cooked up one helluva work of sonic fiction here. Grandiose, epoch-spanning, this is the stuff that dreams are made of. Chillage and Taylor are two of electronica’s Nobel laureates, so that even the luxurious gyrating buzz of their metallic sequencers make nice on the inner ear while their synths gently weep. And hats off to the artists for wearing their analog hearts on their sleeves—the second movements’ slow-twist discourse is equal parts Steve Roach and mentor Namlook, along with a hint of Mark Isham’s score from The Hitcher–emotional environmental music of pearlescent luster and quiet reckoning, drawn with careful poise and an Architect’s touch.
Architects of Existence.credits:
released May 16, 2017
All tracks written by Mick Chillage and Eric "the" Taylor.
Mastered by Matt Hillier for i7x Mastering.

Architects of Existence.title: Fragments of Existence
Architects of Existence.label: Carpe Sonum Records
Architects of Existence.about: Architects of Existence prove that third time is indeed a charm. Not that their first two CS releases were chopped liver, mind you. It’s simply that Mick Chillage and Eric "the" Taylor pool their collective expertise with such synchronicity you can’t help but be utterly enchanted with the sound design on display. Theirs is a magnificent beauty indeed, as the eye peeks into the gargantuan black holes their synths conjure, sights of epic wonder, infinite expanse, and odysseys in to space that mortal man can but dream of. The opening “C18” distills these motifs with its perpetual gaze, as electronics arc and iris throughout an indifferent cosmos, Chillage and Taylor begging kaleidoscopic microdots of errant pulse and vibrant, interstellar hues that shift about the color spectrum. It’s as if the duo are rendering corporeal the very sounds of stardust itself. The sweeping arias of airbrushed sound underpinning the near 19-minute journey of “Haunted Existence” must circumnavigate a whole array of moods and textures, synths that mimic light rays bent awry, digital phantasms percolating betwixt galaxies, the sensations of massive objects moving forever in a night sky drenched in abject melancholy. Just stupendous.
Architects of Existence.credits:
releases February 26, 2026
Written, performed, and recorded at the Igloo Dublin and ForceField Studios, Rochester, NY.
Mick Chillage would like to thank Dave at Carpe for his patience and support, and "The” Taylor for his deep dedication, warm communication and for sharing his boundless talents.
"The" Taylor would like to thank my wife and children for letting me escape to the music room, ForceField, Mick Chillage for continuous magic and patience (Good fun Mick, you’re a gentleman!), Charles B. McLaud, Esq., for continued friendship, belief and guidance, and Dave at Carpe Sonum.

Architects of Existence.title: Three Deep Breaths
Architects of Existence.label: Carpe Sonum Records
Architects of Existence.about: Mick Chillage and Eric “The” Taylor, better known to the ambient cognoscenti as Architects of Existence, return with a follow-up to their earlier self-titled Carpe Sonum debut, and it’s a dandy. Neither artist’s been resting on his laurels these past three years, but whatever spirits they’ve imbibed since has had a pretty dramatic effect on their respective gray matter. To wit, they’ve brought to bear on this superb follow-up a near-telepathic line of communication that has yielded one of this years' most compelling opuses. Imagine taking a literal plunge into the clicking synapses, irising filters, snapping envelopes, and charging whips of electricity at the core of the duo’s gear, audiovisually mapping the results, and pushing the molecules of air outward to yield the mighty textures leaping forth. Does the word ‘epic’ come to mind? These two Architects have crafted a Fax-like artifact for the ages, full of mammoth synths that carve out great chunks of sky and leave the listener riveted in mindstates awash in awe. From the near-symphonic brushstrokes of “Pulling”, which takes on an Michel Huygen/Neuronium-like grandeur, to the pearlescent sequencer patterns adorning “A Trickled Tear”, this dynamic duo effortlessly trips the light fantastic.
